Each chlorine atom typically raises the melting point by about 20°C due to the increase in molecular weight and dipole-dipole interactions. The compound has one chlorine atom, so we add 20°C to our base value. Furthermore, a dimethylcyclohexane ring is present, which introduces steric hindrance and reduces the planarity and symmetry of the molecule, potentially lowering the melting point slightly (estimation: -10°C). Combining these effects, we get an estimated increase of 85°C over the basic biphenyl structure.
